title: Before 17 August 2019, will retirement savings legislation known as the SECURE Act become law?
preds: I have a high level of confidence that it will pass at some point (strong bipartisan support, House wants to pushed through quickly), but doesn't seem likely to pass by Aug 17 given the hold up in the Senate due to the removal in the House version of provisions that would have allowed funds in 529 college savings plans to be used for home schooling costs and supplies for K-12 students, among other objections. Given the 17th is fast approaching I'm not sure they'll be able to overcome the objections raised by certain Senators.

I think with all the reporting that there may be changes in retirement there may be a further outcry by those affected and the financial market that there should be little to no change!   With a combination of support from senior citizen groups and the finance community legislation may be blocked more so!

Due to Senate Recess and the ACT being stuck in Limbo. As the Senate heads into August recess, the SECURE Act remains in limbo. Three Republican senators — Mike Lee of Utah, Ted Cruz of Texas, and Pat Toomey of Pennsylvania — each have holds on the bill, blocking its passage via unanimous consent, sources said. Bill proponents are hoping it gets attached to a piece of must-pass legislation, like a spending bill, when the Senate returns in September.
https://www.pionline.com/legislation/senate-bill-looks-modernize-frozen-db-non-discrimination-rules
Congress is out of session next two weeks

Post mortem lesson:
* I was overly optimistic based on passage in the House which led me to discount base rates for just how few bills become law, and within a short period like this no less. Takeaway - this is a good reminder that passage in the Senate is often more difficult. After all, the Senate was designed to be a more stable institution than the House, more conservative, and more resistant to change, be the bulwark against the vicissitudes of popular opinion, "the saucer that cools the tea" as Washington called it.
* I was overly optimistic because I believe the bill to have bipartisan appeal and be uncontroversial. Takeaway - another good reminder that large pieces of legislation have plenty of provisions that can run individual senators the wrong way (e.g. homeschooling funding in this bill)
* The procedure of unanimous consent in the Senate is a high bar to clear
Other things to worry about in Washington right now (trade wars, intelligence, the Fed).

Congress is in recess and not due to return till September 9th. At that time, three major pieces of legislation still need to be addressed; The Butch Lewis Act, The Retirement Savings and Security Act and.......... SECURE Act.
The probability seems very low at this point. Although it passed overwhelmingly in the House, no action has been taken in the Senate.
Dropping the last few points to zero since the senate is about to go on recess for a month.
This is a do nothing senate.
I am never going to retire I am always going to lead

Reducing by 3% after another opportunity to pass the legislation failed.
https://www.investmentnews.com/article/20190723/FREE/190729972/budget-agreement-leaves-secure-act-by-wayside?NLID=daily&NL_issueDate=20190724&utm_source=Daily-20190724&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=investmentnews&utm_visit=606490&itx[email]=5bffa9cb099383a757c9d55ab79e771535cf3475f1b6dcbb3e2afe64022b0c7d%40investmentnews&X-IgnoreUserAgent=1
Dropping a few points to stay below consensus.

The Senate appears back in session from July 29 through August 2.
Then they're out until September 9.
It is said that Senator Cruz wants 529 money to pay for home school.
He could be trying to extract promises to amend the bill through attachments to must-pass legislation like the debt ceiling and two-year federal budget in order to obtain his support to pass SECURE by unanimous consent.
Or he could just want to go home, use the matter to campaign through August, and "git 'er done" when they come back in September.
Estimates are 1.7MM kids out of 5.3MM kids 5-17 are home schooled in TX - 2nd only to CA
Given very tough race against Beto last year - might be profitable for him to trumpet that about in August.

It has become clear that multiple senators oppose it for multiple reasons including funding for homeschooling and tax cut provisions.  Additionally there is uncertainty as to whether McConnel will bring it up before the recess even if these hold ups are brought along. https://401kspecialistmag.com/politicians-opposing-secure-act-and-why/

Senate split, after passing the House by a large majority:
https://wjla.com/news/nation-world/senate-split-over-retirement-savings-bill Senate recess scheduled for early August.
Ted Cruz is going to cause this to end up in committee.
I am reducing my forecast - the longer it waits, the less chance it will pass.

Best I can tell, the dockett is full meaning limited time to spend debating to get passed by August.  6 Senators are blocking, holding up. Unless there is deal making, I'm just not sure it gets passed that quickly.  Public sentiment might sway, however, coverage to date is low.

This feels unlikely with the short timeline. The senate is away this week and then only has four working weeks (which don't include Fridays) until their month long recess August 5th. It is possible Cruz could drop his objection but it seems more likely the bill will ultimately be tacked onto a must pass budget bill or something similar in the fall.

Hopefully does not pass. :( Looks like the whole idea is "secure" more money for the government.  https://www.forbes.com/sites/jlange/2019/06/11/the-hidden-money-grab-in-the-secure-act/#113251973bbd https://prospect.org/article/democrats-retirement-debacle-and-ted-cruzs-last-minute-save
I don't see Cruz & Co being easily convinced on the matter but otherwise there is little time left or pressure to pass quickly.

This is very good legislation and seems to have a bipartisan support, however, it is unlikely that approval will come as quick as August 17.  The annuity provision for 401ks' is especially needed, By 12.31.2019 yes but not August.

IIRC, base rates for any bill to be passed is about 4%. Considering the small window of time under consideration, this should be adjusted considerably. Some inside view considerations:
- The House bill had 58 co-sponsors (bipartisan) and passed with almost unanimous support (417 - 3) [1]
- Richard Neal, the sponsor of this bill, has introduced 16 bills in the past, only 1 of which became law (6%). [2] 
- Some more info at this link: [3]
- Chuck Grassley, who leads the bill on the Senate side, has a track record of 7 bills passed out of 70 (10%). [2]
- Becoming law also requires a presidential signature as far as I know. This also takes time.  Overall, I give this a chance of 18% probably. [1] https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/1994/
[2] https://thelawmakers.org/find-representatives#/
[3] https://www.thinkadvisor.com/2019/06/12/senate-working-to-pass-secure-act-retirement-bill-grassley/?slreturn=20190527013258

Tried searching for disconfirming evidence on the popularity of the bill, which led me to a less than objective corner [1] which nevertheless allowed me to learn that there is some controversy over annuities.  More importantly however, there doesn’t seem to be any progress on Cruz’ concern about using 529s for homeschooling. To watch: do the supporters of the bill have the ability to offer something to Cruz and the other R Senators who are holding up the bill over the issue of using 529s for homeschooling?  Overall, while I think it’s >50% that some version of this legislation will pass at some point this or next year given its general popularity and bipartisan appeal, there are many possibilities and timelines. The only chance for the bill to go through quickly within the timeframe of this question is for the Senate to follow unanimous consent procedure (which would require Cruz and the other dissenters to be convinced). Other possibilities include going through normal procedures involving debates and significant floor time. Or attaching it to another piece of legislation. Under those possibilities it seems unlikely for the bill to pass in time. [1] https://prospect.org/article/democrats-retirement-debacle-and-ted-cruzs-last-minute-save

The retirement reform bill SECURE Act was passed by the House on May 23 by a large margin of 417-3.  The Senate has its own retirement reform bill called RESA.  Normally the two versions will have to go through a long process of reconciliation to work out their differences.  However, the Senate decided to forgo this length process.  Instead it opted for the "unanimous consent" approach in which the bill will be passed in the Senate if everybody agrees.  This would have speed up the passing of the bill significantly.  However, Ted Cruz objected (placed a hold on the bill) due to his disagreement with the 529 plan in the SECURE Act.   Cruz has been known to be a difficult person to work with, even with the Republicans.  In addition, it is reported that there are objections from other Senators but their identities are unknown.  How do you work on the objections if you don't even know whom to talk to? with the above in mind and the short time frame for the question, I forecast the probability of success of this bill to be below 50-50.   [1] https://www.pionline.com/article/20190604/ONLINE/190609970/senate-working-to-pass-secure-act-quickly

The US Senate is only in session the last 3 weeks in July and the first few days in August. So I think there will be more adjustments to the bill during that time that will delay the ultimate passage of the law.
This could be a win for the GOP in the run up to the 2020 elections.  POstponing it to a moment where it is more politically advantageous in the media might delay its approval

Unless The Current Incumbent comes out strongly for this quite soon, the calendar is not on their side.  It would sort of surprise me if it didn't pass some time after 17 August, but even with strong bipartisan support, this is a tight deadline in the current climate--and also in the current weather, what with summer vacations coming up for the poor exhausted Members.

Historically, 10% of bills become laws [1]. Yet, this is in a different reference case since the bill has already passed the House with a large bipartisan majority. The biggest hurdle is a disagreement led by Cruz against a change recommended by Pelosi. [4] The hold up is likely to be temporary given that there is bipartisan support in the Senate and the disagreement seems to be about a matter that is considered somewhat tangential (529 plans).  The president is expected to sign it according to lobbyists quoted by the WSJ. Therefore, this will likely be a matter of timing. The Senate will recess on August 5, so the bill would have to be passed before then. Therefore it will be important to watch developments in the next week or two to gauge whether it is on track to do so. With regards to timing, it will also be important to watch how/if the Senate reconciles this with RESA: "Otherwise, if the Senate passed RESA and then reconciled RESA with the House-approved SECURE, it would eat up limited legislative days on the congressional calendar." [3] [1] http://www.ushistory.org/gov/6e.asp
[2] https://www.senate.gov/legislative/2019_schedule.htm
[3] https://www.investmentnews.com/article/20190531/FREE/190539980/senate-tries-to-put-secure-retirement-bill-on-fast-track
[4] https://www.cnbc.com/2019/06/21/why-ted-cruz-may-be-blocking-major-retirement-reform-in-the-senate.html

This is an excellent piece of legislation with strong bipartisan support.  Ordinarily this would doom it, but the Orange House hasn't yet pronounced on it.  If The Current Incumbent comes out strongly for it soon and doesn't Twit out a reversal within, say, 48 hours, it should actually be enacted.  If he doesn't come out strongly for it, Distinguished Majority Leader Yertle the Turtle (R-Ky) will continue pretending to be dead and let it languish.  And of course if The Current Incumbent notices that it will help some people who can't do him much good, he may decide to oppose it.  Interesting times, in a train-wreck sort of a way.
It is too easy of a win for an unpopular congress. Most of the changes are trivial at worst and almost significant at best.

With nearly unanimous House support and the prospect of increasing future tax revenues, I think this act will go through in a timely way.  My probability estimate is not higher because the Congress is extremely dysfunctional.
